text.p: The following are the reports carried by Estonia's newspapers on Tuesday. Reuters has not verified these reports and does not vouch for their accuracy:

- The governmental commission for agricultural subsidies will recommend direct subsidies for grain and dairy farmers and is considering customs tariffs for imported pork, Economy Minister Jaak Leimann said at the Rural People's Congress.
- A round table at the culture ministry today will discuss how to solve contradictions between the language law and broadcasting law, officials sad.

- Electoral union Tartu 2000 decided to leave the coalition in Tartu city council, the council chairman said. Reform Party and Centre Party have the backing of 25 council members for no-confidence vote to mayor Tonis Lukas on Thursday.
- A trial over former interior minister Heiki Arike began in Tallinn. Arike is accused of abusing his position and authorising the import of weapons unlawfully.
- A new investigation should be held on the rouble affair, three members of the parliamentary special commission on the rouble deal recommended.
- Estonia is making preparations for opening an embassy in Athens. Estonian charge d'affaires to Greece Juri Arusoo will arrive to Athens on April 9, officials said.
- The police department is planning a major staff reshuffle in the management of eastern Narva prefecture after falsifications of crime statistics.
- Kalev Stoicescu will be the new Estonian ambassador to the United States and Canada, the foreign ministry said.
- The company Soots Tourism could face up to one million kroon fine for presenting false data in a share issue prospectus. The issue has been stopped, officials said.
